active_learning.discussion_prompt: Why did DES designers choose exactly 16 rounds? In small groups, debate the trade-offs between security (e.g., resistance to differential cryptanalysis), performance on 1970s hardware, and why it was later deemed insufficient despite meeting initial Data Encryption Algorithm (DEA) requirements.
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education, specializing in DES '16 Rounds' (Topic Hierarchy: Cybersecurity > 001_Cryptography > 003_Symmetric Cryptography > 002_Block Cipher Algorithms > Data Encryption Standard (DES) > 16 Rounds). Prerequisites: Block Ciphers, Feistel Networks. Generate 40-50 high-quality flashcards using the exact schema: Multiple Choice (1 correct, 3 distractors), Front (question + options), Back (bold correct + explanation + Bloom level + layer). Incorporate: - Learning Objectives: [PASTE FULL LIST HERE] - Scaffolding Layers: [PASTE FULL LIST HERE] (10 cards/layer). - Distractor Protocol: [PASTE FULL PROTOCOL HERE]. - Active Learning Ties: Weave in discussion/peer/problem-solving hints in 20% explanations. Focus EXCLUSIVELY on DES's 16 Feistel rounds: structure (E-box, S-boxes, P-box, subkeys), purpose (diffusion/confusion), security (why 16, differential cryptanalysis). NO PQC, NIST SP 800-63, or unrelated topics. Output as JSON array: [{'front': {'question': '...', 'options': ['A) ...', 'B) ...']}, 'back': {'correct': 'A) ...', 'explanation': '...', 'bloom_level': 'REMEMBER', 'layer': 1}}, ...]. Ensure university pedagogy: active recall, spaced repetition friendly, measurable progress through Bloom's.
